meeting_annotations.speaker: Wenjing Wang
meeting_annotations.transcript: by standard effect. So I think besides visualizing, so it'll be really cool if that we have this data for all these perturbations either mutations that cause like the phenotypes or at a higher level kind of output so that we actually know that perturbation certain processes or these enzyme dynamics or interactions regulations are actually important disease relevant.
meeting_annotations.other: Sandy Schmid has her hand raised using the Zoom reaction feature during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, we need a functional filter there. I see Sandy, I got your hand up there.
meeting_annotations.other: Acknowledges a non-verbal cue (Zoom's raised hand reaction).

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sandy Schmid
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I'm just thinking a lot of the probes we have now, biosensors, for example the classic calcium biosensors or lipid biosensors from phosphatidylinositol are binding proteins that bind calcium or bind to a phospholipid. And we have this amazing technology now of nanobodies and nanobody libraries that can be displayed on yeast and and then also this technology of taking two different binding sites and putting them together so that you could have heterozygous binding sites as opposed to the classic antibody that has exactly the same antigen for both things and that would bring proteins together. So I'm wondering if anybody's thought about using nanobodies and screening for creating molecules that bind to your favorite chemical or would be called a hapten as opposed to an antigen.
meeting_annotations.other: Uses extensive hand gestures to illustrate complex concepts like combining binding sites.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gang-yu Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, that's interesting thought. Yeah, your substrate or enzymes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think people are starting to use those for multiplexed antibody-based imaging, like 40, 50-plex, you know, the CODEX, MIBI kinds of readouts and they're getting all these multi-color images at subcellular resolution. So that's one area. Inside the cell or in the living cell, that's harder, but I'm sure it's going on.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ross Wang
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I have seen people starting to use nanobody to track to see the glycosylation intracellularly.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gang-yu Liu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, so also Sandy, we actually can do single cell surgery just in case the nanobody couldn't enter living cell, we can deliver them in.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sandy Schmid
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well the nanobodies of course are very small, the size of GFP and they can be genetically you know the genetic they can be genetically encoded and are being expressed inside cells, conformational specific nanobodies, they can be expressed in regulated ways inside cells. So this is completely genetically tractable. That's not the issue, it's the binding specificity and off and on rates.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: And the readout, right? The fluor- there must be a nanobody fluorophore that's been expressed that has the fluorescent probe responsive to binding in vivo.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stefano Di Talia
meeting_annotations.transcript: One practical thing, I mean we we thought about one approach like that once in the lab but we were really worried that the binding of the nanobody to the receptor would just mess it up. So there's also like there are some of these sensor, one of the nice thing of the FRET sensor and some of these that were mentioned before is that at least in first approximation are inert. So you could put it in there and your cell is still going to do what it's supposed to do. So that's another frontier I guess, making sure that they work and they work without messing up the cell I guess.
